review.title: An Adaptivity Hierarchy Theorem for Property Testing
review.abstract: Adaptivity is known to play a crucial role in property testing. In particular, there exist properties for which there is an exponential gap between the power of \emph{adaptive} testing algorithms, wherein each query may be determined by the answers received to prior queries, and their \emph{non-adaptive} counterparts, in which all queries are independent of answers obtained from previous queries.

First, we quantify the degree of adaptability of a test algorithm by taking into account the number of "rounds of adaptability" it uses. Specifically, we say that a tester is k- (round) adaptive when he queries in k + 1 rounds, where the queries in the i-th round may depend on the answers obtained in the previous i − 1 rounds. Then, we ask the following question: Does the power of test algorithms grow smoothly with the number of rounds of adaptability? We give a positive answer to the above question by demonstrating an adaptability hierarchy theorem for property testing. Specifically, our main result shows that for each n-N and 0-k test such a property exists.

sections.heading: 3 The Definition of Testers with Bounded Adaptivity
sections.text: In this section, we provide a formal abstraction that captures the notion of limited adaptation within the framework of property testing. (1) We define two terms of limited adaptability: (1) round adaptability, which refers to algorithms that first perform a large number of non-adaptive queries and then a limited number of adaptive queries. We point out that while tail adaptability can be easily emulated via round adaptability, the reversal does not hold. (2) In Section 6.3, we show that round adaptive testers can be much more powerful than tail adaptive testers. Nevertheless, our lower limits hold for stronger round adaptability, while the upper limits are held for more restrictive tail adaptability.

metadata.abstractText: Adaptivity is known to play a crucial role in property testing. In particular, there exist properties for which there is an exponential gap between the power of adaptive testing algorithms, wherein each query may be determined by the answers received to prior queries, and their non-adaptive counterparts, in which all queries are independent of answers obtained from previous queries. In this work, we investigate the role of adaptivity in property testing at a finer level. We first quantify the degree of adaptivity of a testing algorithm by considering the number of “rounds of adaptivity” it uses. More accurately, we say that a tester is k-(round) adaptive if it makes queries in k+1 rounds, where the queries in the i’th round may depend on the answers obtained in the previous i− 1 rounds. Then, we ask the following question: Does the power of testing algorithms smoothly grow with the number of rounds of adaptivity? We provide a positive answer to the foregoing question by proving an adaptivity hierarchy theorem for property testing. Specifically, our main result shows that for every n ∈ N and 0 ≤ k ≤ n there exists a property Pn,k of functions for which (1) there exists a k-adaptive tester for Pn,k with query complexity Õ(k), yet (2) any (k − 1)-adaptive tester for Pn,k must make Ω(n) queries. In addition, we show that such a qualitative adaptivity hierarchy can be witnessed for testing natural properties of graphs. This work previously appeared as “Fifty Shades of Adaptivity (in Property Testing).” Columbia University. Email: ccanonne@cs.columbia.edu.
